title: Triple Deathly Hallows Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm a huge Harry Potter nerd. I saw a Deathly Hallows spinner on here and tried printing it, but it is too big for my hand. This is a much more comfortable size, especially since I intentionally do not put weights into my spinners - need the fidget more than the spin! Plus the weighted ones are more dangerous to my little ones - my husband was playing with one with large nuts in the corners, lost control of it so it went flying and nearly hit our baby in the head - with just the bearing and no weights, I'm less anxious about potential head injuries from this.

I also created a version that the whole spinner is one symbol instead of the symbols in the corners. It's a bit more subtle since the "wand" part is small, with the bearing being the "ring". If someone wants that added, comment and I'll add it. Or you might be able to just delete out the circles and extra "wands" yourself via the Tinkercad link below.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5QPWn6NQC6B

description.text:
I designed this spinner for my 6 year old son since the standard configuration of 4 608ZZ bearings is too big for his hands. The outer bearings are now 625Z bearings with a diameter of 16mm instead of 22mm.

description.text:
My E3D v6 Clone is slightly bigger than the original, so many designs did not fit my hotend and I ended up making my own design (which was pretty hard for me, as I'm still a noob to Fusion 360).

This version will fit 24.8mm diameter hotends.
If you want me to upload version for other hotend diameters, feel free to comment/ask.

First version of the part cooling duct was blowing 90% of the air through the first slot, so there wasn't much air pressure left on the other two slots. I then increased those two slots and the duct size in general, to improve airflow balance.
Still not sure, if I will make some more changes to the duct in the future.

Needed:
M3 Screws for Fans
M3 Screw for Fanduct/Mount connection
M3 Nut to tighten the Duct to the E3D mount

E3D 40mm v2 is for ~24.8mm Hotends, I also added the E3D 40mm_24.1mm for a tighter fit or smaller hotends.

28.05.2017

  • uploaded Part Cooling Duct v4
    Easier to print, less support needed

Printer:

Kossel XL 750mm

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the duct with very little support (in S3D I removed most support inside the duct manually as you can see in the pictures).

The E3D mout can be printed lying flat on the fan side, or standing like the stl file. Lying flat = easier to break when pushing over the hotend, but easier to print (less support).

description.text:
Disc-bound Notebook Systems are very useful and customize-able. There are several different brands in the market - Circa by Levenger, Arc by Staples, Office by Martha Stewart, TUL by Office Depot, IQ 360 by Walmart, etc. and they seem to be inter-changeable when it comes to their accessories.

I am using the Arc System from Staples to keep myself organized. I have different sections for different topics. Some times I need to mark a where I am within each section.

I printed and use tinaw's Parametric todo list stencil (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1610575) with holes for disc-bound notebooks. Modifying her OpenSCAD source file, I made my Disc-Bound Page Marker.

If you print, go with a 0.1mm layer height for increased strength - should give you 5 layers.

Can print in different colors too.

Please share your picts of the different colors you choose to print and use.

title: Batman fidget spinner with enclosed nuts M10

description.text:
I have created this remix in order to check if I can create a new spinner with no visible nuts or any other element used to increase the weight.

The idea is make a pause, put the m10 nuts in the accurate position and continue printing until the end.

IMPORTANT:
This is an in progress design that I have not printed yet to check the functionality, so I will update with extra information and new pictures once I finish to print it.

UPDATE (19/05/2017): As I printed the spinner and I realized that the 608zz bearing does not fit completely (probably because of the printer or slicing settings), I have updated a new v2 of SpinnerBatmanCerrado.stl with a center hole of 0.2 extra mm.

UPDATE (05/06/2017): The spinner center hole has been enhanced in the "SpinnerBatmanCerrado.stl" for a better fit of the 608zz bearing.
The previous lockers to cover the 608zz bearing were not good enough, so I have uploaded a new "TapasSpinnerBatman_V2.stl" file.

Anet A8

No

To have the batman logo with a different color you can make a pause when the printer reach the last layers, change the filament and continue printing. The locks also have a Batman logo, so to make it more visible you can use again the trick of start printing with one color, make a pause, change filamente and resume the printing process.

title: Fender American Standard Tuner Drill Template Jig

description.text:
This is a template to drill the peg holes for Fender American Standard tuning machines. I used a Mighty Mite (MM2928) neck with the 10mm holes predrilled, but I wanted to be sure I got the holes I needed to drill for the pegs on the bottom of the tuners aligned well.
This is what I came up with.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard (.2)

Infill:

50%

Notes:

50% infill, I set it for 5 shell layers instead of the default so that the drill bit didn't break through the side wall of the holes. If I were to print it again, I might just make it solid.
The holes are purposely small. I wanted to work my way up to the appropriate size drill bit (3/32" ended up being a nice snug fit. 2.5mm might be ok if you're using metric?).

Don't use this to drill holes in your neck unless you're 100% sure it's going to give you the result you want. The predrilled 10mm holes in my Mighty Mite (MM2928) neck were very slightly out of alignment, but this worked pretty well anyway (It was a TIGHT fit).

print_settings.Notes:: Best printed laying flat on the bed

description.text:
When assembling and disassembling my Cetus 3D Print I found it oftentimes hard to recalibrate the Y-arm in the Z-direction. This is why I designed these stands. You will need to print them twice

To use them perform the following steps:

  • Turn off power
  • Remove extruder assembly
  • Put the build plate in the middle of the x-axis
  • loosen the bolts of the Y-arm (optionally also from the linear rail)
  • Fix the stands to the arm and place at the far edges.
  • Make sure that the stands rest firmly on the build plate
  • Fasten all the bolts.

You can use my Fusion 360 model here: http://a360.co/2rz3j42

Cetus 3D

I use this as a protector for the Heatbed. you need two of these and put it to the rails.
you need to adjust the z switch so that it switches on the height of the protector.
you can then also level the second side of the x-axis. i designed it because when i tried to switch to auto level the firmware crashed multiple times in the bed. You have also to adjust the bed to this new height.

you should be aware that when you run against the protector the coupler will expand. so be sure that the coupler didnt expand when the endstop is triggered

I believed I would not have to do this kind of things, but since this fashion invaded the schoolyards here, kids just didn't let me any choice :)

They wanted something roundish, comparable to what their friends buy in stores (yes, they are selling them in stores now !). So to avoid to use too much bearing on it, I used instead M8 bolts. bolt caps are provided to be screwed inside using your thumb, as well as central caps. Then only one central 608 bearing is required.

3 version, using 4, 5 or 6 bolts for better balance.

My USB sticks and SD cards are usually on my desk being messy. So i thought of making some sort of holder to put them together.
Edit: I uploaded a new version which is a bit easier on inserting SD cards.

author: rileyd

description.text:
TrussFab Bottle Chair is made of 36 recycled refillable bottles and 8 3D printed connector hubs.

The chair is built from the combination of 0.5l and 1l bottle edges (14 small_small, 2 big_small, and 2 big_big) which are combined by their bottom with tape or screw. The individual bottle size is not very important but the ratio between the small and a big bottle-lengths should be roughly 1:1.3. If you use soft bottles, you can inflate them to achieve better stability. In this case their bottom needs to be taped together, not screwd. According the type of the bottle you are using you will need the corresponding connecting cuffs (refillable or non-refillable). You can also design you own cuff based on our initial design: https://grabcad.com/library/c-cuff-1

To help assembling the structure, there are imprinted ID on the hubs. All what you have to do is to match the numbers, for example: connector 2.5a goes to connector 5.2a, etc. The letters are indicating the size of the bottle edge (a-big_big, b-big_small, c-small_small)

TrussFab is an integrated end-to-end system that allows users to fabricate large scale structures that are sturdy enough to carry human weight. TrussFab achieves the large scale by complementing 3D print with plastic bottles. It does not use these bottles as “bricks” though, but as beams that form structurally sound node-link structures, also known as trusses, allowing it to handle the forces resulting from scale and load. TrussFab embodies the required engineering knowledge, allowing non-engineers to design such structures and to validate their design using integrated structural analysis. We have used TrussFab to design and fabricate tables and chairs, a 2.5 m long bridge strong enough to carry a human, a functional boat that seats two, and a 5 m diameter dome.

You can also find out more about the project here: https://hpi.de/en/baudisch/projects/trussfab.html

TrussFab Bottle Table is made of 48 bottles and 10 3D printed connector hubs.

The table is originally built from 1l bottles which are combined by their bottom with tape or screw. You can use any bottle size/type, as long as they are all the same in the model. If you use soft bottles, you can also inflate them to achieve better stability. In this case their bottom needs to be taped together, not screwed. According the type of the bottle you are using you will need the corresponding connecting cuffs (refillable/non-refillable). These are the most common bottle types, but in case you want to use some other type you can design your own connector cuffs for that. You can also design you own cuff based on our initial design: https://grabcad.com/library/c-cuff-1

To help assembling the structure, there are imprinted ID on the hubs. All what you have to do is to match the numbers, for example: connector 2.5 goes to connector 5.2, etc. The letters are indicating the size of the bottle edge (a-big_big, b-big_small, c-small_small)

TrussFab achieves the large scale by complementing 3D print with plastic bottles. It does not use these bottles as “bricks” though, but as beams that form structurally sound node-link structures, also known as trusses, allowing it to handle the forces resulting from scale and load. TrussFab embodies the required engineering knowledge, allowing non-engineers to design such structures and to validate their design using integrated structural analysis. We have used TrussFab to design and fabricate tables and chairs, a 2.5 m long bridge strong enough to carry a human, a functional boat that seats two, and a 5 m diameter dome.

author: corsara

title: Star Wars Spinners Kylo Ren Remix

description.text:
I remixed Kylo Ren to fit a 608 bearing and also to have a .4mm raised mask so that I could do a multi-color print. So, the main body is 7mm high with a .4mm mask = 7.4mm total height.

How I Did It:
I am sure this would be easy to do in Sketchup, but I downloaded and installed it and didn't even know where to begin so I uploaded the model to Tinkercad and...

First I used a couple of shapes to cut away everything but the side that didn't have the beveled edge and made it 7mm high. Duplicated that and then used the more shapes to cut away everything but the mask and made it 7.4mm high. Then I positioned the mask and grouped them and the duplicated and flipped it. Then I imported the Vader model and cut away everything but the hub to get the 608 bearing. Aligned everything, then grouped it all together. Heck, here it is: https://tinkercad.com/things/0SC1FBJWc81

description.text:
1/8" D shaft skirted knobs are real expensive, I needed a couple so I made these. I filled the pointer line with WhiteOut for contrast.

The photo shows the nut and bolt needed to clamp the knob to the shaft.

It's quite the pain to design this in Tinkercad but you can do it so I did but there's more holes than solids.

I built two versions, one pointer facing flat and one pointer away from flat because to change it later would have been harder in this non parametric modeler. Print the one you need.

VERSION HISTORY:
18_d_shaft_skirted_knob.stl - first version has a small error that causes the screw shaft to remove a small amount of material from the D shaft. Mechanically makes no difference I just cleaned it up when it was noticed.

8 D Shaft Skirted Knob.stl - second version.

8 D Shaft Skirted Knob V3.stl -third version, just the set screw on the back and a bit larger as the first felt a bit small when put to use, also the nut fits in a bit easier and the skirt is a bit thicker. Minor changes but make it nicer to use.

comments.text: Hey there, dig the remix, and wondering if you've tried it yet and what number of poles you're looking for. Asking because just adding more magnets doesn't help with a Halbach, they need to be in a very specific order with as few gaps between them as possible. I've never seen them in 2-part symmetry that you're showing as well, 4-part symmetry works much better for proper pole orientation. And I've never found square magnets aligned across the diagonal, let me know if you find those!

description.text: A dimensionally accurate version of a 0.5 in Balon valve.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm layer height

Infill:

19%

Notes:

I have included the Cura cwprj file used to create this print this valve. It contains in more detail the settings of the printer as well as the orientation of the valve and the location of the supports. The supports were needed due to the design of the valve handle and the requirement of a 0.65 mm clearance around the ball and stem to ensure function.

I have owned a 3D Printer for less than a week. This valve was a test of the accuracy as well as the usefulness of this technology for prototyping in my work environment as a proof of concept.

The STL file was generated by my best friend, John Harvey, from some of his AutoCad work. He designs meter skids for my Natural Gas Midstream company. His 3D models are used to ensure build tolerances when our meters are sent for fabrication.

This was the first print created which included moving parts, ie. the dimensionally correct stem and ball.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I use my trusty Pilot Metro fountain pen all the time. I try to carry some extra IC100 cartridges in my bag, but the cardboard box they come in always falls apart and I end up digging through my bag trying to find them.

I liked the look of the Apple Airpods case so I decided to copy it and re-purpose the design as a cartridge protector. I couldn't get the flip top to work like Apple did, but I used 4 8x3mm magnets to hold the top on. This design holds 6 cartridges, or 1/2 of a box.

I had some troubles printing the top. If your printer bridges better than mine you can proabably print this without supports, but I had to use some inside the top. the outside of the case stays smooth but the inside of the top is a little rough thanks to my supports.

I printed mine with white hatchbox ABS and finished with a coat of XTC-3D and it's shiny and smooth just like the Airpods case.

description.text:
These clips are for attaching a burgee, signalling flag, or other item that you need to hoist up your mast, to a lightweight halyard to make it visible to others. They're not for heavy loads like sails or mooring lines.
I've seen these clips around and thought I could print them much cheaper than I could buy them! The clips are tied onto the ends of a line running up the mast (or flagpole) and slide together into the gap in each clip when held at 90 degrees to each other. Attach them to each end of the halyard using a halyard knot, or whatever you fancy, and attach another set to the rope running through your flag. Unclip halyard ends, clip to flag, run up flag. Simple.
I made two versions, one lightweight and the other much heavier but they are compatible. The hole without a gap is sized for 4mm cord.

title: Fan Blast Door for Heated Build Chamber

description.text:
Since I want a heated build chamber, emphasis on heated, I don't want to be evacuating all of the hot air throughout the print so I designed the blast door so that I can keep it down (~sealed) while the print was ongoing and then flip it up after the print is done to vent the chamber. I ordered a fan controller so I can flip on some fans after I open up the blast door. The fan controller and the fans were meant for desktop computers, but it's perfect for my weirdo application. Eventually I'll set a filter in front of the intake to filter out the ABS fumes/particles, but I haven't gotten there yet.

The design for the blast doors was pretty different for me. Because I had to integrate movement into it, I had to stay super cognizant of where the hinge pin would be during the rotation of flipping it open and closed. I copied the door itself and made several copies of it rotating the copies around the pivot point to make sure they would each clear the opening.

Here's the link to my blog about the build: http://www.candlercustoms.com/heated-build-chamber-part-iii-leds-and-fan-blast-door/
Here's the link from the final build out of the heated build chamber: http://www.candlercustoms.com/heated-build-chamber-part-vi-wrap-up-and-first-print/

If anybody wants a version without the spidey symbol just let me know. My printer being named the Black Widow lends itself to a lot of spider accents.

Here are the associated pieces of equipment I used with the build:
120mm Fans: https://www.amazon.com/Rosewill-Sleeve-Computer-Cooling-ROCF-13001/dp/B00KB8CB9O/ref=as_sl_pc_tf_til?tag=candler-20&linkCode=w00&linkId=5cbbc016323a69750db22d006604f7b6&creativeASIN=B00KB8CB9O
Fan Controller: https://www.amazon.com/HDE-Channel-Multi-Fan-Cooling-Controller/dp/B006UFMH3W/ref=as_sl_pc_tf_til?tag=candler-20&linkCode=w00&linkId=91196c20242d934c4df416d1b8126cd0&creativeASIN=B006UFMH3W
Filament: https://www.amazon.com/HATCHBOX-3D-ABS-1KG1-75-TRED-Dimensional-Transparent/dp/B00M0CS6HA/ref=as_sl_pc_tf_til?tag=candler-20&linkCode=w00&linkId=d0411ca869c2a054899997c95b44f59f&creativeASIN=B00M0CS6HA
[Full Disclosure. These are Amazon affiliate links. I get a small kickback if you order through these links. If I ever get enough traction to get this far it would help me with filament for prototypes, but so far not even that much. :) ]

Let me know what y'all think. Thanks!

Printer:

TEVO Black Widow

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Definitely don't use supports everywhere, if you do you'll have supports inside the rails that the door needs to slide in and out of. I suppose it'd be possible to dig them about, but it'd be a pain.

I built supports for the pivoting hinge into the STL.

description.text:
Those two rings help you insert and remove bearings from your 3D printed fidget spinner - without any damnage for both.

Why I came up whit this idea
I used to insert and remove bearings from my fidget spinner with a rubber hammer. I then realized that hammering the bearing (and his inner cylinder) damnage the spheres inside the bearings, causing a performance decrease.

How the two rings work
The smaller ring is for inserting bearings in the fidget spinner. It's the same size of the external shell of the bearing, so place on it and use a hammer to push it inside the fidget spinner. In this way you hit only the external shell of the bearing and spheres inside will not be damaged.
The bigger ring is for removing bearings from the fidget spinner. Place it under the baring you want to remove and use the smaller ring and the hammer to push it down from the opposite side of the spinner.

Check pictures if it's not clear. Also, if you speak English, please help me with a better description, because I'm Italian and not so good in English language. :-)

Please share a photo if you print it!

Printrbot Play.
The ultimate gear sphere: 32 gears (3 types), small scale, etc. Unfortunately, you also need 32 pieces of M3x10 hex key screws as well. Here is a video.

Print the core, 12 pieces of gear A and B while 8 pieces of gear C. If you want to use 2 M6 hex keys to rotate (see video), print 2 pieces of gear A_hex6 and 10 of gear A, instead. Use the M3x10 screws to mount the gears to the core. The core is a partially truncated version of the dual of the truncated octahedron. The dual of the truncated octahedron is also known as tetrakis hexahedron. The core has 24 not-so-regular pentagonal faces and 8 regular hexagonal faces. Mount gears A and B to the not-so-regular pentagonal faces accordingly, then gears C to the hexagonal faces. Gear A has 27, gear B has 18 while gear C has 21 teeth.

I have printed out my sphere gear but seem to be having some issues with the gears binding up. I have each gear VERY loosely screwed in so that it can move 'up' away from the other gears to keep it from binding, but I notice that gears are actually hopping teeth when this happens. Is there something that I did wrong? I seem to have found the correct pattern in gear placement but am not sure if I got it right.
So my base question is this: should the gears not mesh 100% of the time and be free to hop teeth? Or did I manage to assemble it incorrectly? Can we get some more detailed instructions on the actual gear assembly/placement other than "Mount gears A and B to the not-so-regular pentagonal faces accordingly"?
Great model overall though, everyone I show it to is impressed! :D
comments.author: xzosimusx

comments.text: If you mount gears C to the hexagonal faces, then all of the remaining faces will be identical at that moment. So, if you pick a gear, say, gear A and mount it to one of the pentagonal faces, then all of the remaining faces won't be ambiguous. Hopping is not allowed. Just cross-check these, i suppose then it should work. I don't expect that any special settings are needed for printing, however, the teeth are rather fine...
comments.author: xzosimusx

I'll take it all down and see if I can redo it.
So just to be sure I am understanding, what you are saying is that you should have the C gears surrounded by either A or B gears overall? Not a mix?

The smaller gears (B and C) are connected to only gears A. There is no edge where B and C match and drive directly each other. Note also that gear B is the smallest and not gear C. So, gears C are surrounded (connected or driven by) only gears A. There is no connection between the same type of gears.
Sorry if some parts of the description was ambiguous...

print_settings.Notes:: It printed upright without a problem.

description.text:
Version 3:
The tab I added to the back under the belt clip has been enhanced. The one I added in version 2 lasted for the event. However, when demonstrating it to people, it showed its weakness. I decided to make it thicker, and add a rib. From memory, I believe that it was the correct height. If it is, and breaks off again, I will just make it a solid block. I may be testing this as early as this coming July 3rd at Finish on the 50 10k road race at Gillette Stadium.

Version 2:
I left previous version text below incase you were interested in history. For version 2 I completed all the changes that I posted about below. I also rode the Tour de Cure using the version 2 bracket.

A couple of observations: 1: all the changes had the effect that I was hoping for. 2: If I make any more changes to the model, it will be to move the cg up so that the radio might balance where I put it better. Somehow, I don't think I will go this route. Instead, I might sandwich some rubber (wide latex rubber band pieces) between the bracket and handle bars. 3: I used an sma 45 deg connector to keep the antenna aimed in the desired direction.

Version 1:
I am riding the Tour de Cure which is an event to fund the American Diabetes Association. I am also working the event in communications during my ride. I wanted another option for carrying my radio than clipping it on clothes. Other designs on this site did not work for me.

This is a work in progress. I am relocating the slot for the belt clip, as it is too low. I am also changing the radii for the handlebars. Currently the radius is 31mm. However, MY handle bars are only 31mm at the center and taper and angle to the rider. This may/may not work for you. My bars are 30mm and 23mm where I am attaching the bracket. I am also changing the relief for the cable tie to allow for a shorter tie. I might add something to keep the radio from being able to move front to back to keep it from rattling on the road.

Printer:

P3steel Prusa clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I print on a glass heated bed @60. I printed this in petg @245. I print on aquanet (thanks Andy). For this print, I used Cura for slicing. I know that the way I have it set up, it uses a very minimalist support structure. I designed this to not need supports, IF you can manage to keep it stuck to the bed. 2 - 3 minutes before the print started, I gave the bed a heavy douse of spray. With the long path and small footprint, large overhangs, I knew that it might be a challenge keeping it attached to the bed.

It printed upright without a problem.

I started by searching for designs that were already out there that may suit my needs. Examining them, I came to the conclusion that I didn't care for the pocket that enveloped the whole radio. I also couldn't find the appropriate mount.

I decided that I wanted to use the belt clip as part of the securing method. Then I noticed the groves for the battery charger dock. It was at this point that the design pretty much made itself. I have AutoCAD at work, so this is what I use.
faire la boite puis les blocs en quantité (25% de leur grandeur) et jouer a tétris

Parametric spinner in Fusion360 based on 2ROBOTGUY's drawings. Autodesk link to latest version: http://a360.co/2q1n1o5.

Go to Modify->Change Parameters to change relevant dimensions. As presented, sized to hold four quarters as weights (24.26 mm), as that gives the heaviest weight using US coins. Using a weight_od of 22 gives the usual four bearing spinner. See here for other coin sizes. With a 608 bearing, you can only hold as many coins as will stack into 7mm. 4 quarters turns out to be exactly 7mm.

Because of the edge fillets, best results are obtained by printing as two halves, then carefully aligning and gluing them. Most slicers can split a model by dropping the model down through the bed by half the width (3.5mm).

Also contains drawings for my threaded caps.

description.text:
This is a 20mm t-slot beam where I have optimized several corners to keep the 3d prints from bulging. If you look at the measurements in the CAD diagram you will see some little "mouse bites" that I made concave in places a 3d printer can generate excess plastic.

I matched the groove width, center opening, and curve width to official drawings of the:
80/20 Inc., 20-2020, 20 Series, 20mm x 20mm T-Slotted Extrusion

This provides maximum compatibility with parts you can order online and lets you order aluminum in bulk if your prototyping works out. At least that's my plan :)

comments.text: Great design but the hinges broke after opening it about 2 times. Also, you should make it harder to get the hinge apart in the back so there isn't so much separation.
comments.author: RappmanD

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment.
I assume that the reason the hinge broke was from the orientation of the bottom piece when on the print bed. I did this twice with my Super Magical Chest. The reason I cut the bottom piece in half was so that you could print the hinge in a way that it won't break. The bottom of the chest I made has two parts glued together. I recommend that you orient the the bottom piece so that the the split in the middle is parallel to the build plate. The orientation of the layers will strengthen the hinge. (but it means more support material)

this is a ballbearing I created for fidgetspinners.
I designed it to work with 4.5mm steelballs. But you can also use any other kind of balls. (like 6mm BB's. For that, you just have to change the sice of every part in your slicer up to 134%)
It is a bit fiddly to remove the ridges inside the outer part. Please don't despair on it. It's worth it. Here is a youtube video with instructions how to assemble a ballbearing:

This is not my Video and not my channel!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OyxpQDFikMc

When you assembled the whole bearing, you have to glue the two ballholders together (yes, you have to print this part twice, because at this sice it is nearly impossible to make this one a snap-fit part)

Have fun with it and impress some of your friends ;)

Brackets for a 3D printer enclosure. Bottom bracket slots are intended for 3mm sheets of acrylic - let me know if you need me to add brackets for different widths. I'm going to build my enclosure with 3mm acrylic and I'll upload photos once it's done. There's a vent & filament piece for mounting in a 30mm hole in the top of the enclosure. Top brackets will be glued onto the acrylic to strengthen the enclosure. I'll use hinges already on thingiverse for the door opening at the front.

Included DXF files for laser cutting the acrylic with included holes and door. These DXF files will make a 600x600x600 enclosure.

To complete the project you'll need the following:

  1. 5 sheets of acrylic, preferably laser cut to size. I've provided DWG files for a 600x600x600mm enclosure including cutouts for the vent hole, cable hole and door. For the top sheet, you'll need a 30mm hole cut for venting and filament feeding. For the front sheet, you'll need a hole cut for the door and you'll need to offset the door 80mm from each perimeter (because the brackets are 75mm). Optional: on one piece, cut a 40x40mm hole, offset by 80mm from an edge for cable access (use the cover for cable hole piece for this)
  2. Print:
    4x Bottom brackets
    4x Top brackets
    1x Vent/filament hole
    1x Door catch (either 10x2mm magnet or 20x2mm magnet
    Optional: 1x cover for cable hole
  3. Glue and fit together. Print 2 hinges (eg https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1396038) and attach door

title: Rolling Spool Holder v1.1 (customisable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATED: Changes to file names and updated description.

With this Spool Holder you can conveniently make customisable changes to accommodate a variety of different spool sizes.

Print 4x base sections, 4x wheels and pins. Place the base on a solid surface and push the pin/wheel assembly into place, this will require some effort but will give you a nice satisfying click when it pops in to place.

Now decide the size of the spool is going to sit on the roller.

Spool width:- Simply select the file Spool Width file that matches the width of your spool, so if your spool is 100mm wide then you print the 100mm Spool Width file, your left and right wheels will now be at 100mm centers from one another. 120 then 120 Spool width, etc.

Spool depth:- This one is trickier, but print a size that makes sure your spool is sitting nicely between the back and front rollers. Again 100mm Spool Depth gives you 100mm between the centers of the back and front rollers.

Two versions of the wheel is present, one with the pin in the center and one without. Print the ones you feel comfortable with.

I've uploaded a few size of joiners and centers so hopefully everyone is happy, if not just get in touch and I will add sizes.

Please remember to remove any elephants foot to make the parts slide together easier, if you still find them a little tight then give them a rub down with sand paper or an emery board/nail file.

author: Trudge

description.text:
A 3D mockup of a tantou (Japanese short-sword) I am making as a present for someone and an excuse to buy new tools and learn several new fabrication techniques.
I plan on eventually building a forge and making the blade in the traditional manner myself. Before I do so I was advised to make it in wood, then aluminium, then plate steel before attempting to forge it from scratch.
The blade part (including tang) tend to be 1 tsuba (about 30cm or 12") long and about 2.5cm 1" wide and 8mm 1/3" thick.
Although intended for ritual suicide or personal protection they were often worn as fashion items.
The version shown here is an aikuchi type, where the handle, finger guard and scabbard are all flush with each other. These were more dangerous to use but easier to conceal.
The wooden version is progressing well!
Note: all parts including new version 0.3 parts (From February 2013) are included in the zip file!

Wooden Version:
  • Choose 2x2x24" block of hardwood suitable for carving and polishing (I chose white sycamore)
  • Cut in half length wise giving 2x 1x2x24" strips
  • Cut each plank in half giving 4x 1x2x12" strips (these will be the blade and the 2 halves of the scabbard)
  • Cut the one leftover short plank in half to give 2x 1x2x6" blocks (these will be the halves of the handle
  • Mark and rough-out the shape of the blade with a plane, saw, sander etc.
  • Once the shape is roughed out as desired, smooth all corners and add pseudo sharp edge (@ 30 & 45 degrees) and groove (called a 'hi') if desired
  • Carve recesses to match the shape of your tang into the handle halves
  • Carve recesses to match the shape of your blade into the scabbard halves
  • carve a finger guard (tsuba) to fit the shoulder of your blade from a scrap of fancy looking wood (or 3d print it)
  • Test assemble using loose fitting dowels and clamps and adjust if necessary
  • Polish and sand along entire length until smooth flush continuous surface is obtained along entire length
  • Disassemble and perform final drilling, carving, finishing, polishing, staining on all parts.
  • Clamp, dowel and glue all parts together (do the scabbard separate to the other parts)
  • Once dry paint, varnish, decorate as desired
    • Now you can try to make it in a more challenging material!
Printed for surgery planning form tomography
Printed for surgery planning form tomography

title: LED Light Shade for mounting on PC Heatsinks (parametric / Freecad)

description.text:
I made this light shade so I would not get blinded by a 7W LED.
The disign is straight forward, I used the base area of an old mainboard heatsink plus its mounting holes to define the outline. From there I just extruded a funnel so the light would only shine down and not in my eye. There is a 10x2,5mm opening on the side to let the cables through. I'm providing the Freecad file so you can change the model by your desire, it also helps retracing the steps of how I made it. Freecad: http://www.freecadweb.org/
I used black ABS for printing with a 5mm nozzle. Sadly i got a problem with warpage. I will spraypaint the inside with silver/chrome acrylic paint to get better reflection.

While searching for Nintendo Switch mods and accessories I found the Single Joy-Con Grip by 3DBotMaker and was thinking of printing a pair when I noticed a comment mentioning that it would be nice to offset the Joy-Con within the grip to compensate for the stick and button offset. So I decided to modify 3DBotMaker's model and see what I could achieve in that regard.

The final result doesn't center the controls perfectly but it's much better than before. The stick and face buttons are still slightly off center which actually leaves the shoulder buttons slightly off center in the other direction.

I haven't printed the version I'm uploading but I did print a prototype. The uploaded version was adjusted to correct a few issues I discovered when I actually tried fitting a Joy-Con into the prototype. I'll be printing another soon and I'll upload a picture of the final result.

description.text:
Inspired by aapocketz Drop-in car dock design I made this remix.
Basically I built it from scratch, but due to the inspiration I wanted to give aapocketz the credits.

This holder is designed for use with the Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge without any cases etc. Just the bare phone.

The hole in the bottom has been designed to fit a WesternDigital Harddrive Micro USB Cable (oval shape). It is a VERY tight fit and you need some elbowgrease to get it in. But once it is there, it won't come out.
The phone slides in, and snaps into place. Even the roughest bumps wont let your phone fly through the car.

In the bottom of the holder I added a horn-type outlet for the speaker of the phone.
It improves clarity when answering a phone call without a handsfree system.
Works quite well in my opinion. Better than a speaker that fires down...

description.text: The Apollo Soyuz Test Project was conducted in 1975 between the United States and the Soviet Union. It was the first incident of cooperation between the two countries in space and had a resounding impact on political tensions between the countries in the middle of the Cold War. Now, for the first time ever, you can 3D print both the Apollo 18 Command Module and the Soyuz 19 spacecraft and dock them together yourself. Designed to scale with slight manipulation on each craft so that they can be joined together when printed.

title: PSVR AIM Stock top/bottom mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an adjustable Stock for the new PSVR Aim Controller. All the Buttons are still reachable after the stock is mounted.

This is still a prototype and will probably get changed slightly in the future if it needs to^^

Update 21.05.2017: Added mounts for the bottom as well. Just print the mount files with the bot at the end instead of the normal ones.

You need this Parts to build one:

2x AIM_stock_mount_A or AIM_stock_mount_A_bot
2x AIM_stock_mount_B or AIM_stock_mount_B_bot
1x AIM_stock_headmount
1x AIM_stock_head

8x M4 Screws with min. 10mm or max 16mm length
8x M4 nuts
2x aluminium square shape tubes with 10x10mm or aluminum square profile 10x10mm both with 500mm length for top and 350mm length for bottom mounts

The length of the tubes on the pictures is 500mm maybe you want them longer or shorter but i found that length comfortable for me.

Assembly:

Put all the nuts in the intended hex shaped holes and attach the Parts AIM_Stock_mount_A and AIM_Stock_mount_B to the Controller slightly lose and make sure you can still move them around a little bit. Then put in one of the tubes to both mounts and place them like on the pictures and fasten the screws for the mounts itself not for the tubes. Remove the tube and push both of them in the headmount as far as possible. Screw the head on the headcount with the 2 remaining scews and put the stock back in the mount.

Be careful not to scratch the controller with the aluminum !

Finally fasten the 4 screws that hold the tubes in place and happy shooting =)

Dremel

title: Desiccant Box V2 - NO SANDING
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT: Updated to V2!
I've made some improvements since I initially posted this thing. New in v2:
-Made slots slightly smaller to reduce the chance of broken beads falling out
-Fixed slot spacing to be the same on every face
-Added a smaller version

Original Summary
I went looking for a plain, rectangular desiccant box but the first one I printed was too small and the second required too much sanding. So I gave up and designed my own! It has a snap-on lid and requires no sanding.

The large size absorbs moisture quickly and allows me to go longer between bake-drying my desiccant. The smaller size is better suited to smaller enclosures and vacuum bags.

If you print with ABS you can bake-dry the desiccant in the box. I dry mine at 220°F (104°C) for several hours with no problem. I've tried PLA and it tends to sag a little bit at this temp. But if you dial back the temperature and bake for longer you'll probably be ok. Another option for PLA is to dump the beads into a pie tin to bake, then let them cool completely before putting them back in the box.

description.text:
I used this to pull R&G 1" heated grips off.

Puller requires 8mm threaded rod and an M8 nut. Screw the nut onto the thread rod, heat it up (e.g. on gas hob!) and then push into the hex hole.

Use 2 more M8 nuts on the opposite end of the threaded rod tightened together to allow the rod to be rotated with a spanner.

  • Unscrew the chrome end cap from the heated grip.
  • Place a 1p into the pusher.
  • Insert the pusher into the heated grip.
  • Screw the puller onto the heated grip.
  • Use a spanner to tighten the threaded rod.
  • Go slowly. Wait some time between tightening quarter turns until it starts to move.
  • May help to switch the heated grips on (but not too much otherwise the PLA can soften.

Notes:

I printed using PLA.

When printing, rotate so that the hollow is up and the flat faces are down!
This is a NEMA-17-compatible THING with three spools. The outer spools are wider than the center one making it pull wire slower. There are holes in each spool base to tie a thread if desired.

title: La Cerradura Doble - sliding key puzzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
La Cerradura Doble

This is a remake of a puzzle I've seen online: http://smallpuzzlecollection.blogspot.de/2011/11/la-cerradura-doble.html. The original puzzle was limited series only and is long sold out, but I figured out from a photo how it went together and decided to remake it to have a try at solving it.

I have not invented the puzzle itself, however the printable 3d-CAD design (including all the engineering that went into making this printable from opaque plastic) has been made by me.

printing and tolerances

If your printer is accurate, the puzzle will be smooth in operation and there will be a gap of 0.2mm between the lid and the base. Since the top layer is slightly rough always, the gap will pretty much be closed by the imperfections of the top layer.
If your printer is a bit out of whack as far as extrusion goes, you might need to put M2 washers between the lid and the base on each screw.

The whole thing is designed with 0.2mm gap round about moving parts, and all sliding parts slide along layers, so it should operate rather nicely. The biggest fun killer is if your corners of the base part lift-off.

Print in contrasting colors (lid and keys different color from base and sliders), else it's an eye strain to figure out what gets locked by what.

The puzzle itself:

get both horizontal keys out of the system and then put them back. To achieve that you will have to move the five vertical sliders and move the keys in proper order.
The keys are different from each other and fit as pictured (round corners to the outside).
Have fun.

author: printmagic

description.text:
Two pencil holders for helping to assembling George Hart's amazing 72 Pencil sculpture ( http://www.georgehart.com/sculpture/pencils.html ). When finished, they can also be used as a stand. There is a useful assembly example here http://sumidiot.blogspot.co.uk/2008/11/72-pencils.html
and http://www.instructables.com/id/Geometric-sculpture-from-72-pencils/ Lardcanoe has also created a nifty holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16293

Buy 72 pencils (mixed bright colours are fun); measure your pencils across the flats - mine were 6mm. Scale the STL so that the longest distance across the holder (the hexagon diagonal) is 16 times the pencil across-flats distance, so 96mm for this holder (i.e. 16*6mm).
There are two designs of holder, one which is solid, the other which is thinner and can flex a little. It's probably easier to start with the #2 (the springy one); as the solid one can be tight fit to the pencils. Print 4 holders - one to hold each of the four hexagonal prisms of pencils (18 pencils per prism). Push two of them together at an angle of ~70ÃÂÃÂ° (or arccos(1/3) if you have a calculator & protractor ;-) so that the hexagonal prism edges (are parallel and the pencils touch. Add the next prism so it's also ~70ÃÂÃÂ° from the others. Cross your fingers and push in the last prism.
Elastic bands around the assembled prisms can help keep them in place while assembling.
Discrete drops of superglue will help keep everything together, especially for the pencils along the edges of the prisms. To help visualise how things go together, I've included a ZIP-ped STL file of the full assembly (72 pencils & 4 holders) which you could view in, say, ReplicatorG. Note: The holder was drawn up in a CAD package, but I have tried an OpenSCAD version - just not sure if the maths is completely correct.
I'm still tweaking the size of the pencil holes and their separations - if things are too tight, try printing the holder ~5% bigger. This prints reasonably well on a Makerbot Replicator. (Although the first holders were made of balsa wood with CNC milled holes.)

comments.text: Just noticed this one. I like it! The design you have was actually my original way (i should have uploaded it as well), but I couldn't get my ToM to print something with a print area that large, so I had to break it up into smaller parts leaving me with a slight imperfection. I was probably a tenth of a mm off which meant the pencils didn't hold as well. Yours looks nice and strong, but I guess you also had to resort to some glue. Good work!
comments.author: lardcanoe

comments.text: I liked your holder (quite envious of your idea of splitting it up) and I hope it was alright putting a link to it.  I did it the other way round - the rigid one first, then the flexible one (which is much more tolerant on pencil variations).

title: Feiyu Tech G5 18650 battery case (18650 to 22650)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Instructions:

  • Print in a flexible filament
  • use a sharp knife to cut where the print is fused together (spiral line)

  • for most 18650 batteries you will have to solder a very small pad inside your Gimbal, without this the flat positive side is not going to make contact.

title: Tevo Tarantula - Bracket right base with inverted z-motor mount

description.text:
Updated version available!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393178

This is a combination of @tomfrayers dual inverted z motor mount (right) and the R_base bracket by @thingirob. I used 123D Design and Meshmixer for its contruction. Made it very fast and could be improved, but for know it works very nice.

This work is in progress. There are some issues in the stl made by Meshmixer, but in cura it worked for me.

Due to the close distance between the motor and the x-carriage I recommend printing @thingirob's z_nut_mount and z_nut_inner as well. These add two degrees of freedom to the thread and will also work if you haven't adjusted the xy-position 100% correctly.

Don't forget to invert the z-axis in your firmware.
Cheers

If you need to print it on a 100 X 100 bed, you can rotate it so one of the sides with the mounting holes faces down by rotating it in the Y axis 135 degrees, but you will lose strength.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text: My entry into the PRESS RESET longboard challenge. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pVH-GfD4Sfo Print the V8.STL file AS IS, don't rotate. While it does require two, one for each front wheel, there is no left or right side to this, as it can simply be flipped to hang it on the wall the other way using the other holes. It's mirrored on both sides. Designed for number #10 screws. I also designed it to use washers or fender washers for added strength, but not required. It should handle 90mm or smaller wheels without a problem. In the pictures you can see my test rig and the hanger right after I took it off the printer. There is one test with a fender washer, and one test with no washers at all, just the screw. The hanger held a full 5 gallons of water, plus additional weight from the bucket (1 pound 9 oz) and the clamp (1 pound 6oz) during both tests. While it deformed, it never broke or separated. The hanger also sat out in the California sun with the weight, which probably attributed to the deforming of the hanger. The 5 gallon bucket never touched the ground, it was always well above the ground. #SKATEFORCE

description.text:
This is a minimal size/weight antenna mount for the EMAX Babyhawk that uses the screws' extra length on the camera to securely mount to the top of the quad.

I printed it in TPU. I imagine other filaments would work just fine. It's not robust, but it's not meant to be. I wanted to keep it as light as possible while routing the antennas away from the propellers.

The design may be altered in the future but this does the job for me for now, and it only takes a few minutes to print. :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

Doesn't matter.

I got the plans for this from http://homemadepuzzles.co.uk. They have some great looking puzzles and this is one of the plans they have for free on the website. I included the solution PDF in the files.

The 2 top sliders with pins need to be put in the box before gluing on the lid. Loctite gel super glue works much better on PLA the regular super glue, I recommend it.

Print out one of each piece, except the Lower A and Lower B. Either print the hollow version or the solid version of the Lower sliders. I recommend printing the hollow ones for the fun of being able to hid something in the puzzle.

I have supports in the STL files the should be easy to remove, and should make it so your slicer doesn't need to put in supports.

I also have a print service: https://www.treatstock.com/3d-printing-services/kasza-printing
I would be happy to print it for you.

Printer:

TEVO tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%

comments.text: Unfortunately I don’t think this puzzle will work as drawn. There needs to be more clearance below the two upper side slots so that those two blocks, with their pins, can slide out when released from the grooves in the lower blocks.
comments.author: lignumaqua

comments.text: The 2 sliders with pins are locked in the box, that is how the plans that I used to make this model were drawn. But what you suggest is a great idea, it would be nice to be able to remove all four sliders.  I will work on that when I have a chance.
comments.author: lignumaqua

comments.text: Thanks for responding. I made one and I'm afraid that nothing comes out as it is. The pins need to be slid outside the box to release the bottom sliders. If you look at the drawings http://homemadepuzzles.co.uk/Green%20Slidey%20Plan.pdf you can see that the bottom slots extend up significantly above the side slots. The stls here don’t have that feature.
